bio: My name is Ryan Hughes and I'm a grad student in French & Francophone studies at UCLA studying contemporary French critical theory, identity politics, and community planning/organizing.
I recently completed my masters and am now hoping to transfer my research interests and passions into a career in architecture, starting with a masters in architecture.

pyrite.title: pyrite
description: Conceptually, this project explores the intersections of orthographic projection, scale and form. The form of the overall structure is defined by the intersection of two cubes of equal size, one rotated 45 degrees from top, right, and front view. The result of this rotation creates a symmetrical structure in which the outline of the un-rotated cube is preserved in specific viewpoints. Because its symmetry is not perpendicular to the ground, in perspective the form appears to always have one surface slipping away from view. A grid of 400 5’ x 5’ windows is projected orthographically onto the residual square outlines that exist in elevation. This frame problematizes scale as the grid of warped windows intersect floor plates and appears to belong to a structure much larger than eight floors. More graphic than it is structural, an interior core supports the frame made out of a significantly lighter material like fiberglass or spandrel glass.

To accommodate 160,000 square feet of leasable office space without warping the form’s symmetry, the interior is scaled to have a 50-foot-high, 10,000 square foot lobby proceeded by seven floors, 15-foot high each. The structure is supported by three-foot thick steel beams along with four concrete cores that together include two fire stairs, four elevators, and eight bathrooms per floor. These key structural elements start at the base of the building and finish at the roof. Each floor is subsequently supported by a grid of one-foot-thick beams aligned to the same grid as the steel beams in an orientation that highlights the division of the floors between front and back. The floor plans are certainly not typical plan as the floor plates shift with the tapered exterior, yet the cores remain in the center of each plan and provide starting points for separating the floors evenly between two or more tenants. No floors include demising walls so that each floor can be subdivided at the tenants’ request, providing an ample amount of freedom to customize the lofty interiors. The contrast between interior and exterior for the building is thus defined by the freeform, adaptable interiors with irregularly-arranged concrete cores juxtaposed with the highly ordered geometric exterior and complementary frame.
